articles.headline: Bank Earnings Fall, but Investors Seem Relieved
articles.snippet: JPMorgan reported a drop in earnings of 50 percent in the first quarter, but beat Wall Street’s expectations.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan reported a drop in earnings of 50 percent in the first quarter, but beat Wall Street’s expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, the bad news looks like good news.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: A Drought in Australia, a Global Shortage of Rice
articles.snippet: The collapse of Australia’s rice production may foretell some of the effects of global warming on agriculture.
articles.abstract: The collapse of Australia’s rice production may foretell some of the effects of global warming on agriculture.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENILIQUIN, Australia  Lindsay Renwick, the mayor of this dusty southern Australian town, remembers the constant whir of the rice mill. “It was our little heartbeat out there, tickety-tick-tickety,” he said, imitating the giant fans that dried the rice, “and now it has stopped.”

articles.headline: Chinese Student in U.S. Is Caught in Confrontation
articles.snippet: A student who acted as a referee between a pro-Tibet vigil and a pro-China group has been accused of being a traitor.
articles.abstract: A student who acted as a referee between a pro-Tibet vigil and a pro-China group has been accused of being a traitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C.  On the day the Olympic torch was carried through San Francisco last week, Grace Wang, a Chinese freshman at Duke University, came out of her dining hall to find a handful of students gathered for a pro-Tibet vigil facing off with a much larger pro-China counterdemonstration.

articles.headline: Retailers Get Stingy With Data
articles.snippet: Faced with an economic slump, a growing number of national retailers are abandoning the tradition of reporting monthly store sales and forecasting profits.
articles.abstract: Faced with an economic slump, a growing number of national retailers are abandoning the tradition of reporting monthly store sales and forecasting profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. C. Penney says the tumultuous economy is making it impossible to predict earnings over the next year. Macy’s asserts that providing monthly sales information is too distracting and confusing. And Starbucks argues that annual profit estimates are unnecessary.

articles.headline: Clinton Uses Sharp Attacks in Tense Debate
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton warned that Barack Obama would be deeply vulnerable in a general-election fight.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton warned that Barack Obama would be deeply vulnerable in a general-election fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Barack Obama found himself consistently on the defensive as he and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton met Wednesday night in a tense debate that left him parrying questions and criticism on issues including values, patriotism and his association with onetime radicals from the 1960s.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: A Grand (i.e., Cool) Piano
articles.snippet: Disklavier’s Mark IV is the first piano with an Internet connection and includes a variety of tricks.
articles.abstract: Disklavier’s Mark IV is the first piano with an Internet connection and includes a variety of tricks.
articles.lead_paragraph: What do you think: In times of unemployment, rampant foreclosures and imminent recession, would it be tasteless for me to review a home entertainment component that costs $42,000?

articles.headline: New Museum Offers the Official Line on Tibet
articles.snippet: The Chinese Communist Party’s unflinching line on Tibet’s historic status has fueled Tibetan resentment.
articles.abstract: The Chinese Communist Party’s unflinching line on Tibet’s historic status has fueled Tibetan resentment.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Not far from National Stadium, the city’s mammoth, just-finished Olympic arena, another construction project is still facing an Olympic deadline. The building, sheathed in a green construction tent, will house Beijing’s first museum exclusively dedicated to Tibet.

articles.headline: Did Ending Regulation Help Fliers?
articles.snippet: Before deregulation, tickets were expensive and routes were limited. Thirty years later, the question is raised anew: Has deregulation really worked out?
articles.abstract: Before deregulation, tickets were expensive and routes were limited. Thirty years later, the question is raised anew: Has deregulation really worked out?
articles.lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, airline deregulation was supposed to fulfill two main goals: spurring competition and bringing down airfares.

articles.headline: G.E.’s Shortfall Calls Credibility Into Question
articles.snippet: Wall Street analysts are suggesting the breakup of General Electric after an unusual earnings shortfall.
articles.abstract: Wall Street analysts are suggesting the breakup of General Electric after an unusual earnings shortfall.
articles.lead_paragraph: For seven lean years, Wall Street has given General Electric and its chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the benefit of the doubt.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Claudia H. Deutsch

articles.headline: EBay Chief Says Change Isn’t Over
articles.snippet: John Donahoe, the new chief of the Internet’s largest e-commerce site, wants eBay to operate less like an unruly flea market and more like a strip mall.
articles.abstract: John Donahoe, the new chief of the Internet’s largest e-commerce site, wants eBay to operate less like an unruly flea market and more like a strip mall.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  More changes are coming to eBay, and John Donahoe, the new boss, is girding for the repercussions.
